Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Coordination Mechanisms for Performance-aware Virtualization in Clusters

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Virtualization technology is rapidly being adopted in modern cluster platforms that support performance-sensitive applications such as web services, real-time financial transactions, data mining, eScience, and E-commerce. State-of-the-art techniques for virtual machine (VM) scheduling, allocation, and migration often treat the VMs in isolation rather than within the context of other VMs and the cluster environment with which they constantly interact. This project investigates cluster-wide coordination mechanisms that exploit inter-VM and VM-cluster interactions to improve both application performance and cluster utilization. The research targets four specific directions: (1) improving timeliness across inter-VM interactions for time-sensitive applications, (2) virtualizing cluster-wide memory resources to support large memory and large dataset applications within VMs, (3) exploiting inter-VM dependencies to guide VM migration decisions, and (4) reducing network fabric contention through coordinated network access across VMs and virtual clusters. Broader impact of the project will be in the development of virtualization technologies that better support performance-sensitive applications in emerging data centers and high-performance computing clusters. Educational impact will be in training technology experts in virtualization, strengthening the experimental computer science curriculum at Binghamton University, and mentoring of undergraduate, minority, and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Virtualization has become a key enabler of modern cloud computing platforms over the last decade. This research made several advances in the technology behind Virtual Machines (VMs) by developing cluster-wide coordination mechanisms that exploit inter-VM and VM-cluster interactions. These techniques improved both the performance of applications that run within these VMs and resource utilization across the cluster.

Intellectual Merit: The key research outcomes of this project were as follows: (a) An approach to virtualize cluster-wide memory resources in order to transparently support large memory and large dataset applications within VMs; (b) An approach to reduce network fabric congestion in datacenter networks through explicit coordination between cluster hosts; (c) A post-copy approach for VM migration that allows for quick eviction of a VM from the source machine and its resumption at the target machine; (d) An approach for simultaneously migrating multiple VMs that exploits content similarity in memory pages of the VMs being migrated; (e) Techniques to improve timeliness in inter-VM interactions between co-located virtual machines; (f) Demonstration of the feasibility of VMs that run over multiple hypervisors, either on different or same physical machines; (g) Techniques for limiting the lifetime of confidential data in VMs that run in the cloud.

Broader impact: The project led to new techniques that better support performance-sensitive applications in virtualized infrastructures. Some of the developed techniques, including cluster memory virtualization and gang migration, led to patent filings and licensing. A number of graduate and undergraduate students were trained as experts in state-of-the-art virtualizaiton technologies and research in experimental computer science. Most undergraduate participants were supported under the NSF Research Experience for Undegraduates programs. A number of local high school students also participated in a summer internship program organized by the PI over five years to learn about computer science careers and systems research.
